text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-Minister of Interior Murr said there is no security tapping of cellular telephones.
-The pro-Iranian Hizbollah killed a pro-Israeli militiaman and wounded four in a rocket attack in south Lebanon.
-The Bank of Lebanon's gross foreign exchange reserves rose by $30.71 million in the second half of March to $6,321.49 million.
-Israeli artillery shelled inhabited areas in south Lebanon.
-The weekly treasury bill issue of March 27 raised 426 billion Lebanese pounds. The issue posted a nominal surplus of subscription against maturity of 138 billion pounds.
-Employees of public utilities will start an open-ended strike on Thursday to pressure the government for pay demands.
Bank of Beirut sold 20 percent of its shares for a value $10.4 million.
-Teachers at the state-run Lebanese University will hold a one-day strike on Thursday to protest against the government's academic decisions.
